channel.title: Master Feed (Updated every 30 mins)
channel.description: Master Feed (Updated every 30 mins) generated by script

item.title: Javier Milei has won a fresh mandate to remake Argentina
item.description: A thumping win for his party in the midterms means his radical economic project gains new strength

item.title: ‘History Is Made’: Timor-Leste Becomes ASEAN’s 11th Member
item.description: The country's admission caps off a 14-year journey toward accession, but also presents new challenges for the Southeast Asian bloc.

item.title: Why Rare Earths Are About to Cost a Lot More
item.description: Contrary to Trump’s claim, diversifying the supply chain won’t drive down prices.

item.title: How to Make AI More Useful
item.description: The obsession with powerful large language models overlooks the developing world.

item.title: Losing the Swing States
item.description: Washington is driving the BRICS to become an anti-American bloc.

item.title: Indonesia’s Soldier Economics
item.description: President Prabowo Subianto, a former general, is bringing a military mindset to economic policy.

item.title: In Malaysia, Trump Presides Over ‘Peace Accord’ Between Cambodia and Thailand
item.description: The agreement builds on the ceasefire of July 28, but is unlikely to resolve the fundamental causes of the current border dispute.

item.title: The Kremlin’s blitz to make Ukraine “go dark”
item.description: Dive-bombing drone attacks aim to shatter its energy system as winter approaches

item.title: Xi Jinping is at his boldest and brashest. How will Donald Trump fare this week?
item.description: What 14,000 communications over 13 years tell you about China’s evolving leader

item.title: China’s secret stockpiles have been a great success—so far
item.description: Xi Jinping is desperate for Trump-proof access to food, fuels and metals

item.title: The counterintuitive economics of smoking
item.description: How cigarette manufacturers profit from quitters

item.title: Checks and Balance newsletter: Rural America reckons with Donald Trump
item.description: Charlotte Howard, our Executive editor and New York bureau chief, considers how the president’s policies are impacting his base

item.title: Canada Seeks New Trade Partners in Asia After Trump’s Blowup
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney hopes to decrease Ottawa’s dependence on Washington.

item.title: Is the U.S. Ready for War With China?
item.description: U.S. military planners are caught in an impossible dilemma.

item.title: Plush Power
item.description: How Labubu dolls became China’s first contemporary cultural export.

item.title: What in the World?
item.description: Test yourself on the week of Oct. 18: Japan swears in its first female prime minister, Russia conducts military drills, and a museum heist stuns France.

item.title: Under New Leadership, What’s Next for Japan?
item.description: It’s a been crazy few months in Japanese politics.

item.title: ‘A House of Dynamite’ Isn’t Explosive Enough
item.description: Kathryn Bigelow’s nuclear thriller is terrifying—but falls short of true provocation.

item.title: It’s (Still) Henry Kissinger’s World
item.description: A new documentary argues Nixon’s secretary of state learned the wrong lessons from his experiences with Nazi Germany.

item.title: The East Wing demolition is a parable of the Trump presidency
item.description: Appraising the president’s architectural plans

item.title: Trump’s Anti-Worker Foreign Policy
item.description: By cutting U.S. support for labor rights around the globe, Washington is hurting workers at home and abroad.

item.title: Revisiting the Indo-Pacific Discourse: Why Pakistan Must Look Seaward
item.description: The Indo-Pacific should not be viewed as a threat, but as an opportunity for Pakistan to expand its relevance.

item.title: How China’s Coming 15th Five-Year Plan Will Reshape Military Innovation
item.description: Beijing is creating an integrated ecosystem where civilian technological innovation automatically serves military purposes: the final evolution of “Military-Civil Fusion.”

item.title: Even Doomsday Will Divide Us
item.description: Megha Majumdar’s “A Guardian and a Thief” interrogates how the have-nots get by in a climate catastrophe.

item.title: Karina Milei, Argentina’s most powerful woman, faces a storm of criticism
item.description: Ahead of vital elections Javier Milei’s sister is adding to his political woes

item.title: Indian Farmers Struggle as Climate Change Warps Landscape
item.description: Once-thriving crops are poorly adapting to new temperatures.

item.title: Cover Story newsletter: How we chose the cover image
item.description: An exclusive look at how we designed our cover

item.title: The Taboo That’s Killing Pakistani Women
item.description: If Pakistan truly wants to protect its women, it must first dismantle the silence and shame that surround their bodies.

item.title: Can you eat your way to lower cholesterol?
item.description: Veggies, nuts, soya and seeds are all a good idea

item.title: The world has become surprisingly less grumpy
item.description: But our analysis of polling data shows an uneven recovery in how people feel

item.title: ASEAN at a Crossroads
item.description: Can Malaysia's ASEAN Community Vision 2045 succeed in reversing the region’s fragmentation?

item.title: Restricting Internet Access Is the Taliban’s Latest Ploy to Cut off Afghanistan’s Most Vulnerable
item.description: Human suffering and unchallenged radicalization open the door for a security crisis of cataclysmic reach.

item.title: China’s De-Americanization Strategy
item.description: As the U.S. pursues “de-risking,” China is charting its own course from reliance to autonomy.

item.title: China, the US, and the Most Expensive Divorce in History
item.description: The smart move now is to prepare for a world divided into two systems: one American, the other Chinese.

item.title: The Trump Administration’s Latest Assault on Workers
item.description: In 2024, the US Federal Trade Commission freed millions of Americans from a powerful constraint on their labor-market mobility by banning non-compete clauses for most workers. It was one of the biggest policy wins for American workers in recent years – and, because of Donald Trump's administration, it may never take effect.

item.title: When Chinese Propaganda Goes Viral in Taiwan
item.description: Chinese state media recently popularized an old video of Taiwanese legislator Wang Shih-cheng, The twist? Wang is pro-independence.

item.title: Israel-Japan Relations Amid the Gaza War
item.description: What, if anything, has changed for Tokyo’s Israel policy since Hamas’ October 7, 2023 attack?

item.title: China Wants to Exorcize ‘Ghost Kitchens’
item.description: As the country’s takeout market has swelled, so have the numbers of unregulated, unsanitary restaurants

item.title: The Perils of Economic Centrism in a Polarized World
item.description: Few ideas in economics have been as misrepresented as the link between debt and growth. More than a decade ago, a prominent analysis was falsely cast as a call for austerity when, in fact, it showed something far more mundane: countries burdened by heavy debt often have limited room to invest or respond when crises strike.

item.title: Thailand, Cambodia, and a Competition Over Territory and History
item.description: Far from a bilateral crisis, the border clashes have implications for the region and world.

item.title: At UNGA, Central Asia’s Discourse on Russia-Ukraine Conflict Shifts
item.description: As Washington redefines engagement and Moscow reclaims relevance, Central Asia is quietly mastering the politics of poise.

item.title: Managed Instability: China’s Quiet Preference for a Contained Afghanistan
item.description: Beijing appears to have realized that sustainable peace in Afghanistan will require more effort than it can spare.

item.title: Is Bolivia Ready for Paz?
item.description: The conservative president-elect has an economic crisis in his inbox.

item.title: A Conundrum for Australia’s Liberal Party
item.description: The country’s primary conservative party – the Liberal Party – is struggling to find resonance among the stability-minded Australian population.

item.title: Modi to Skip ASEAN Summit in Kuala Lumpur
item.description: There were hopes of a Modi-Trump meeting at Kuala Lumpur. That will not happen now.

item.title: UN Treaty Signing Highlights Vietnam’s Curb on Online Dissent
item.description: The Cybercrime Convention will further entrench control and surveillance over peaceful expression of dissent online beyond the borders of repressive states.

item.title: The Geopolitical Significance of Historical Precedent
item.description: The cycle of rise and decline over the centuries has established some basic tenets of power, including that civilizations can still collapse even when they are set up for success. This lesson is relevant for today’s world, in which short-termism and populism risk derailing what should be a bright future.

item.title: The German Economic Miracle, Then and Now
item.description: Why did Germany, defeated in both World War I and WWII, recover so strongly after the latter, but not after the former? Two new books suggest that conventional accounts of the Wirtschaftswunder – West Germany’s miraculous economic ascent after WWII – get it wrong.

item.title: What to Expect From the Upcoming ASEAN Summit in Malaysia
item.description: The summit and its associated meetings, which will be held during October 26-28, are shaping up as the most significant in years.

item.title: Xi May Have Miscalculated on Rare Earths
item.description: China’s complex new rules take on the entire world at once—and give Trump an opportunity.

item.title: For Its 80th Birthday, the U.N. Needs More Than a Reset
item.description: Going back to first principles has until recently spooked many diplomats.

item.title: The New African Order
item.description: How Nigeria and South Africa can lead the continent to prosperity and stability.

item.title: Rising to the Challenge: A Coordinated Approach to Southeast Asia’s Online Scamming Problem
item.description: A transnational threat requires a transnational response.

item.title: UK, Vietnam Planning Major Diplomatic Upgrade, Report Claims
item.description: The two nations will reportedly establish a Comprehensive Strategic Partnership when Communist Party chief To Lam visits London next week.

item.title: The Difficult Art of Bibi-Sitting
item.description: The Trump administration is working to uphold the fragile Gaza cease-fire.

item.title: The EU, U.S. Hit Russia Where It Hurts
item.description: Sweeping sanctions packages aim to curb funding for Moscow’s war effort.

item.title: With Hundreds of Kidnappings, South Korea Grapples With Cambodia’s Organized Crime Wave
item.description: The human trafficking and online scam industry will affect the future of South Korea’s relations with all of Southeast Asia.

item.title: When the Waters Rose: Taiwanese Solidarity in Guangfu
item.description: Within hours of the disastrous flood in Hualien County, volunteers poured in from across Taiwan.

item.title: Will America’s new sanctions on Russian oil force a peace deal?
item.description: Donald Trump raises the pressure—but he may have to go further

item.title: Will Trump’s Russia Oil Sanctions Finally Sway Putin?
item.description: The threat to Moscow’s oil earnings is huge. But will it be enough?

item.title: More Central Asian Banks Sanctioned by the EU
item.description: Central Asia's banking and crypto sectors have been increasingly targeted by the EU, U.K., and the United States for sanctions.

item.title: Ukraine Needs a “Victory First” Aid Strategy
item.description: While Western countries have been generous in supporting Ukraine since Russia’s full-scale invasion in 2022, their financial assistance can be used only for non-military purposes. Instead of deploying aid this way, which creates distortions that undermine Ukraine’s war effort, foreign donors should directly fund defense spending.

item.title: Pakistan’s Year of Diplomatic Miracles
item.description: Islamabad has pulled off repeated coups—but can they last?

item.title: Uzbek Cleric Mubashshir Ahmad Sentenced After Extradition from Turkiye
item.description: With only a two-and-a-half year prison sentence, the harsher punishment seems to be the closure of his entire platform aimed at religious discussions.

item.title: Can Japan-South Korea Relations Continue to Thaw Under Lee and Takaichi?
item.description: Not long ago, it would have been laughable to imagine Lee Jae-myung and Takaichi Sanae as leaders that would foster friendlier ties between these countries.

item.title: Confronting Pakistan’s Deadly Trifecta of Terrorist Groups
item.description: The TTP, BLA, and ISKP are three distinct types of militant groups, each exploiting Pakistan’s security vulnerabilities with distinct ideologies, objectives, and tactics.

item.title: Three Key Questions About Trump’s War Against Drug Boats
item.description: Experts believe the operation is about regime change in Venezuela.

item.title: Two Asias: Illiberal Regimes and Democratic Resistance
item.description: An emerging group of illiberal democracies – including Trump’s America – is aligning with authoritarian states to systematically dismantle the post-war international order.

item.title: What Africans Want from COP30
item.description: Instead of continuing to wait for aid, Africa is seeking to mobilize investment in its green transition, not because rich countries “owe” Africans – though they do – but because Africa can help the world tackle climate change. Success will require progress on four fronts, all of which will be addressed at COP30.

item.title: India Warily Welcomes the Taliban
item.description: A diplomatic visit highlights the cautious engagement between New Delhi and Kabul.

item.title: How Britain Was Pulled Into a Chinese Spying Scandal
item.description: The U.K. government faces accusations that it dropped an espionage case to safeguard diplomatic and trade relations with China.

item.title: The China Factor in Australia-US Relations
item.description: Australia’s strategic footing remains shaped by decisions made elsewhere – like the upcoming Trump-Xi summit.

item.title: Taiwan’s Next Defense Test: From Buying Unmanned to Acquiring Autonomy
item.description: Taiwan is buying things, but is it actually acquiring the capabilities needed for deterrence?

item.title: To save the world’s tropical forests, learn from Brazil
item.description: Last year it lost more rainforest than any other country. Yet there is hope

item.description: That alone will not halt the rise of online fraud

item.description: It wants to become a trading hub for the precious metal

item.description: Indonesia’s mineral riches continue to clash with its green goals. A new law has been passed to regulate mining and protect the environment and local communities, but its enforcement remains weak.

item.description: Skilled labor is the missing link in China’s industrial transformation.

item.title: The Vatican’s Voice of Reason on AI
item.description: For the Holy See to weigh in on a topic like AI may seem unexpected. But the Catholic Church has a venerable tradition of leadership on pressing technological and social issues, and it is uniquely positioned to influence public debate and policymaking.

item.description: Southeast Asia serves as Beijing's operational testing ground for cyberattacks. It’s time the U.S. started paying attention.

item.description: Geography, demographics, religion, technology, and a state’s institutions determined why certain states exercised power and how different regions developed the way that they did.

item.description: A common border with India, transport links, and regional connectivity make Delhi an essential ally in maintaining the industrial base of Bangladesh.

item.description: Addressing the military's impunity and supporting the emerging "pluralistic state," is the only effective way forward for the bloc.

item.description: The collapse of the Al-Khoziny Islamic Boarding School in East Java on September 29 led to the death of 63 students.

item.description: The country has barred Israeli gymnasts from participating in this week's 53rd FIG Artistic Gymnastics World Championships in Jakarta.

item.description: Vorapak’s resignation is among the aftershocks of the U.S. government's recent imposition of sanctions against a major alleged Cambodia-based scamming network.

item.description: Ahead of the meeting, the NATO chief stoked the U.S. president’s ego and brushed off concerns about a lack of progress in cease-fire talks.

item.description: Despite the best efforts of Donald Trump and Scott Bessent

item.description: The birds were almost wiped out during China’s Great Leap Forward

item.description: Some weather forecasts can now be done on a laptop

item.description: It is oddly tolerable for Democrats and Republicans, at least for now

item.title: How to make immigration palatable in a populist age
item.description: Guest-worker schemes are booming. They offer vast benefits to both host countries and the workers themselves

item.title: Why China Is Worried About Japan’s New Prime Minister
item.description: Takaichi Sanae is hawkish on China, friendly toward Taiwan, and ultraconservative on historical issues. No wonder Beijing isn’t happy.

item.title: Afghan Allies File Lawsuit Against Trump Administration’s Barring of Their Families
item.description: The travel ban policy specifically states that it does not apply to asylees or refugees, and yet the families of asylee Afghans, who fought alongside Americans, have been consistently denied entry.

item.title: Balancing Ethics and AI Innovation
item.description: Disregarding ethical considerations in the name of AI innovation – the direction taken by the US – is a recipe for disaster. But pretending that lofty ethical principles will solve the real governance challenges AI raises is similarly misguided.

item.title: After Gaza, Israeli politics are even less predictable
item.description: The trauma of the war may affect next year’s election in surprising ways

item.title: When the State Defines Who You Are: Taiwan’s Pingpu Recognition Debate
item.description: A new law passed last week recognized Taiwan’s Pingpu peoples, reigniting debate over who gets to define indigeneity.

item.title: Intel, Nvidia, and the Asia Factor in the US’s Unconventional Sovereign Wealth Fund
item.description: Insights from Winston Ma.

item.title: Takaichi Is Officially Prime Minister. What Now for Japan’s ‘Iron Lady’?
item.description: Her road to the premiership was not easy. Governing might be even harder.

item.title: Xi’s Purges Reveal His Insecurity
item.description: From surveilling and repressing Chinese citizens to firing and prosecuting potential rivals, Chinese President Xi Jinping seems able to rule only through fear. But fear is not a foundation for long-term stability, and the more Xi seeks to consolidate power, the more vulnerable his position becomes.

item.title: New Zealand’s Strategy for the East Asia Summit and APEC
item.description: Christopher Luxon is heading to Asia for a diplomatic double-header. What are his main goals?

item.title: North Korea Launches SRBMs Ahead of APEC Summit in South Korea
item.description: Amid speculation of a North Korea-U.S. summit on the sidelines of the APEC meeting, North Korea launched short-range ballistic missiles on Wednesday.

item.title: What Does Doha and Ankara’s Mediation Mean for Pakistan’s Fight Against TTP?
item.description: Pakistan has made its position clear that the ceasefire’s success hinges on the Afghan Taliban acting to prevent TTP attacks from Afghan soil.

item.title: Repeating Past Mistakes? The EU’s ‘Change Through Trade’ Approach to Uzbekistan
item.description: Russia serves as a sobering reminder for the EU as it deepens relations with Uzbekistan: economic interests should never override core values.

item.title: The Limits of Engagement in Afghanistan-Pakistan Relations
item.description: Where once Islamabad and Kabul could calm tensions between them bilaterally, external mediation was needed this time around.

item.title: In Beijing and Delhi, Sri Lankan Prime Minister Aimed to Balance Consequential Relationships
item.description: Colombo cannot control the temperature between its two largest partners, but it can control its own predictability, competence, and integrity.

item.title: How Norway’s War Profiteering Could Help Ukraine
item.description: As the European Union tries to put together a large loan for Ukraine, sovereign guarantees and the risk they pose to member states' credit ratings have become a stumbling block. Fortunately, having raked in tens of billions of dollars from the fallout of Russia's invasion, Norway could break the impasse.

item.title: China’s chipmakers are cleverly innovating around America’s limits
item.description: They are pushing tools to the edge, scaling up and relying on fuzzy maths

item.title: Wanted: a new finance writer
item.description: An opportunity to join the staff of The Economist

item.title: The Global Majority’s Fight for Economic Justice
item.description: Amid a series of cascading crises, civil-society groups and NGOs from across the Global South will meet with their Global North allies on the sidelines of the upcoming G20 Leaders’ Summit in Johannesburg. The aim is to develop a locally rooted but globally connected program of action for achieving economic justice.

item.title: In Photos: Life on Cambodia’s Front Lines
item.description: Soldiers stand guard in Oddar Meanchey as civilians make the best of things after being evacuated to displacement camps during the border fighting in July.

item.title: Taiwan Is Not for Sale
item.description: America can make a good deal with China without abandoning the island.

item.title: Golf simulators and gyms are luring Americans back to the office
item.description: Landlords are using “amenity buildings” to appeal to remote workers

item.description: Europe readies itself to survive in a world of hostile strongmen

item.description: He could still survive a currency run and knife-edge election

item.title: What’s Japan’s Problem with Foreigners?
item.description: Anti-foreigner sentiment is on the rise as Japan wrestles with how to keep its identity intact amid plummeting birth rates.

item.title: Supply-Chain Economics Beats Tariff Politics
item.description: Twenty years ago, China learned the hard way that once supply chains reorganize, they never return to their previous form. By relying on tariffs and subsidies, the United States is now paying the price for underestimating how tightly its economy is bound to the rest of the world.

item.title: Why are American women leaving the labour force?
item.description: Maybe they are becoming tradwives. Or maybe there is a more straightforward explanation

item.title: Product Scorecards Can Help Rescue Europe’s Green Deal
item.description: While Europe’s competitiveness concerns are understandable, inaction on social and environmental challenges also carries high economic costs. Rather than resign itself to stifling its nascent sustainability-disclosure regime under pressure from the US, the EU should devise a new system based on products, not industries.

item.title: France’s Political Dramas Threaten More Instability in Violence-Wracked New Caledonia
item.description: Political turmoil in Paris has hindered implementation of the Bougival Accord. In New Caledonia, the accord is also looking shaky.

item.title: Will There Be Brakes on Japan’s National Security Policy Under Takaichi?
item.description: Komeito had long restrained the LDP’s more hawkish tendencies, especially on China policy. What will happen now that it’s no longer in the coalition?

item.title: Glimpses of a Power Struggle Within the Chinese Military High Command
item.description: The string of purges in the PLA suggests an existential struggle between the old and new guard. And now there’s a clear winner.

item.title: Submissiveness as the Key to Womanhood: Traditional Gender Roles in Kazakhstan
item.description: The political elite in Kazakhstan remains stuck in a mindset that belittles women and confines them to submissive roles.

item.title: What Does the Market Really Think About AI?
item.description: Despite all the enthusiasm for AI, which has undoubtedly demonstrated impressive capabilities, the signal from bond markets suggests that investors are unconvinced that the technology will generate sustained or widespread growth, let alone a more extreme positive or negative outcome. What accounts for this disconnect?

item.title: Pakistan’s Enduring Afghanistan Problem
item.description: Relations between the two neighbors have been deeply troubled since Pakistan’s very inception.

item.title: Australia, US Sign Critical Minerals Framework
item.description: In a skillful display of targeted diplomacy, Albanese came to his White House meeting with Trump bearing gifts.

item.title: LDP, Nippon Ishin Coalition Agreement Locks in Takaichi’s Prime Minister Victory
item.description: The LDP found a new coalition partner, but Prime Minister Takaichi is still short of a majority in the lower house.

item.title: Takaichi Sanae becomes Japan’s first female prime minister
item.description: Hawkish on security policy, dovish on fiscal policy and traditionalist on social policy, she will move her country to the right

item.title: BCDA’s Legacy: Turning Former Military Bases into Engines of Growth
item.description: The Bases Conversion and Development Authority proves that smart partnerships can transform underutilized Philippine properties into economic powerhouses.

item.title: Pakistan Cracks Down on Tehreek-e-Labbaik Pakistan
item.description: Last week, authorities arrested thousands of TLP leaders and supporters. The government is taking control of mosques operated by the radical group.

item.title: Measuring AI’s Economic Impact
item.description: Despite the hype and vast sums pouring into AI, we still lack convincing evidence that it is transforming the global economy or boosting productivity and growth. Without reliable data on its uses and benefits, we cannot tell whether we are witnessing a genuine transformation or yet another speculative bubble.

item.title: Vietnam’s Upgrade to Emerging Market Status, Explained
item.description: The recent decision by the index provider FTSE Russel reflects the country's maturing market conditions and improved regulatory climate.

item.title: China Against China
item.description: Xi Jinping confronts the downsides of success.

item.title: The Right Way to Finance Ukraine’s Defense
item.description: Supporting Ukraine with a reparations loan drawing on frozen Russian funds is the right choice not only morally, financially, and legally, but also politically. With Ukraine's economy devastated by the exogenous shock of Russian aggression, Western leaders have a chance to show that they are equal to the moment.

item.description: The Pasni-Gwadar duel represents not just competition between two ports, but a profound restructuring of Eurasian logistics.

item.title: Public AI Is the New Multilateralism
item.description: In the 1970s, European governments worked together to create an aircraft manufacturer capable of competing with the US firm Boeing. As a handful of private companies in Shenzhen and Silicon Valley race to entrench their AI dominance, similarly bold cooperation among middle powers has become imperative.

item.title: The New “China Shock” Is Hitting Poor Countries the Hardest
item.description: China’s continued dominance in low-skill export sectors reflects not just efficiency, but deliberate policy choices that prevent poorer countries from climbing the development ladder. If it truly aspires to global leadership, it must stop tilting the playing field in its own favor.

item.description: Announcing the official launch of the Nordic Kansai Business Alliance (NKBA).

item.title: Europe Must Address Its Disastrous Demographics
item.description: International institutions and think tanks have published detailed warnings about Europe’s demographic decline since the turn of the century, but to no avail. Political and business leaders have studiously avoided planning for population aging, even though it poses a serious threat to financial stability.

item.title: Are We in a Financial Bubble?
item.description: While there is ample reason to believe that AI-driven investments are in bubble territory, the real question is when – and how – the end might come. For anyone hazarding a guess, the lessons of past bubbles, combined with key financial-market indicators, offer a useful guide.
